author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Tsitsipas Is the Latest to Come Close, and Learn How Far He Must Go
description: Stefanos Tsitsipas took a two-set lead over Novak Djokovic in the French Open men’s final. But in his loss he found that “two sets doesn’t really mean anything.”
content: PARIS — The atmosphere seemed as if it was designed to make a Greek feel at home in his first Grand Slam singles final.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Netanyahu may still lead the Likud party.
description: But prominent rivals within the party are motivated to run against him in any primary, accusing him of hurting the bloc with his stubbornness.
content: The vote to oust Mr. Netanyahu may change more than Israel’s leadership. It could also ultimately affect who leads Mr. Netanyahu’s right-wing Likud party.
source.name: The New York Times

title: From The Sunday Read Archives: ‘My Mustache, My Self’
description: How one writer’s facial hair experiment in quarantine led to a deep consideration of his Blackness.
content: During months of pandemic isolation, Wesley Morris, a critic at large for The New York Times, decided to grow a mustache.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: New York Has a Housing Crisis. How Would the Mayoral Candidates Fix It?
description: New York City’s affordability problems were laid bare by the pandemic. Mayoral candidates offer solutions, but steep political and logistical obstacles remain.
content: New York City’s leaders have been vexed for decades by a problem that has helped turn the city into a worldwide symbol of inequality: As years of prosperity gave rise to soaring luxury apartment towers, public housing crumbled and affordable neighborhoods vanished.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy and Steven Erlanger
title: It’s Angela Merkel’s last G7 summit. What will the group be like without her?
description: Angela Merkel, who plans to step down as Germany’s chancellor after the country holds elections in September, is attending her final Group of 7 summit this weekend.
content: Angela Merkel, who plans to step down as Germany’s chancellor after the country holds elections in September, is attending her final Group of 7 summit this weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Donald York, Musical Director of Paul Taylor Company, Dies at 73
description: Mr. York, a former child prodigy who was raised on jazz and choral music, wrote scores that matched Mr. Taylor’s eclectic choreography.
content: Donald York, a prodigious conductor and composer whose inventive scores as the longtime musical director of the Paul Taylor Dance Company matched Mr. Taylor’s eclectic choreography, died on June 3 in Temecula, Calif. He was 73.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Breakdown of Myanmar’s Health System Takes Its Own Toll After Coup
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, June 13, 2021.
content: “I know there are hundreds of people dying per week. Of course, I feel sorry and very sad for that, but the most important thing for our country is to bring down the military. If not, our future generations and our country will die.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Porter
title: Without vaccines, Haiti struggles to contain its latest Covid wave.
description: One hospital near the capital, Port-au-Prince, issued an alert telling patients not to come because its wards were full.
content: Haiti was spared the worst of the pandemic last year, but the coronavirus has returned to the poorest country in the Western Hemisphere with a fury. The nation’s leading newspaper is full of obituaries and hospitals are turning away patients.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Yankees Rally to Tie Before Losing in Extra Innings
description: Aroldis Chapman faltered again in a walk-off loss. The Mets, meanwhile, cruised past the San Diego Padres.
content: PHILADELPHIA — Jean Segura scored Ronald Torreyes with an infield single in the 10th inning for his second straight game-ending hit and the Philadelphia Phillies got a third consecutive walk-off win with an 8-7 victory over the Yankees on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear and David E. Sanger
title: No longer limited to the ‘raise hand’ button, G7 leaders are shaking hands again.
description: As President Biden and six leaders from the world’s richest nations meet — face-to-face — in a picturesque seaside resort in Cornwall, on England’s southwestern shore, it is the first in-person global summit since the pandemic shut down travel and forced presidents and prime ministers to reach for the “raise hand” button, just like everyone else.
content: As President Biden and six leaders from the world’s richest nations meet — face-to-face — in a picturesque seaside resort in Cornwall, on England’s southwestern shore, it is the first in-person global summit since the pandemic shut down travel and forced presidents and prime ministers to reach for the “raise hand” button, just like everyone else.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg
title: How to Pick a Marathon Training Plan
description: There are endless training resources online and groups that meet and train together in person.
content: So you signed up for a race in a bout of excitement. Maybe you started running during the pandemic and can now add a race to your docket, or you missed having a goal on the calender, or perhaps you are finally running a race rescheduled from April 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Something You Can Always Count On
description: Andrea Carla Michaels and Doug Peterson deliver a dependably excellent Monday puzzle.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — There’s something to be said for dependability! The sun will always rise, the mail will always be delivered, my dog will always bark when the mail is delivered (every time, without exception) and these two constructors will always produce a clever, meticulously constructed crossword puzzle. Between the two of them, Andrea Carla Michaels and Doug Peterson have a whopping 126 New York Times puzzles to their names, many of which are collaborations. Surprisingly, given those numbers, this is their first Times collaboration with each other, but you wouldn’t know it from the smoothness of the grid or the playfulness of the clues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronen Bergman
title: On top of Bennett’s to-do list is coordinating with the U.S.
description: The new prime minister sent a strong signal that he, too, would oppose a new nuclear deal with Iran, but is otherwise seeking to mend fences with the Biden administration.
content: Among the most important issues that the new Bennett government will confront is how to manage political, military and intelligence coordination with the Biden administration, which will affect how it addresses almost all other foreign, national security and economic policy challenges. At the center of current dialogue is the soon-to-be-concluded, revived nuclear deal with Iran.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Mickey Levy is the Knesset’s new speaker.
description: Parliament selected Mickey Levy, a lawmaker from Yair Lapid’s centrist party, Yesh Atid, to be its new speaker on Sunday afternoon.
content: Parliament selected Mickey Levy, a lawmaker from Yair Lapid’s centrist party, Yesh Atid, to be its new speaker on Sunday afternoon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Siegel Bernard
title: Winning Bidder Paid $28 Million for Ticket to Space With Jeff Bezos
description: Four people will be aboard the New Shepard, the Blue Origin rocket named for the first American in space, when it is set to launch.
content: An auction winner paid more than $28 million for an 11-minute ride into space alongside Jeff Bezos, on a reusable rocket launched by his space company, Blue Origin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Israel’s parliament ousted Benjamin Netanyahu
content: The Israeli parliament formally ousted Benjamin Netanyahu, whose 12-year reign as prime minister was the longest in the country’s history. The Knesset approved a new coalition government by a single vote: 60 to 59, with one abstention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: Early Voting Begins in Wide-Open Race for New York Mayor
description: Voters seem most concerned about quality of life issues and public safety. They are also trying to figure out ranked-choice voting.
content: On the first day of early voting in New York City, Michael and Eunice Collins voted together in Harlem. Both are worried about the city, but they are divided over who is the best person to fix it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong
title: Explosion at Produce Market Kills at Least 12 in China
description: The cause of the blast, which took place in the central city of Shiyan, was still being investigated.
content: A gas explosion at a produce market killed at least 12 people and injured 138 others, 37 of them severely, in central China on Sunday, the local authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen and Adam Rasgon
title: Tumult Disrupts Israeli Parliament as Netanyahu Era Ends
description: Naftali Bennett, heckled and insulted, replaced Benjamin Netanyahu as prime minister by the narrowest of margins.
content: JERUSALEM — Heckling and mayhem in the Knesset, an intimate parliamentary chamber transformed by anger, marked the end of Benjamin Netanyahu’s divisive 12-year rule over Israel and the start of Naftali Bennett’s term as prime minister.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘I Watched From the Back of a Taxi as He Skated In and Out of Traffic’
description: Encountering an East Village character, an unusual question and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Marcus Payadue
title: Israel, G7, French Open: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: Netanyahu’s Road Through Israel’s History, in Pictures
description: A photographic journey shows how ‘Bibi’ put his stamp on Israel — through his toughness and the search for security in an unstable region.
content: “Bibi, King of Israel!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall
title: As Biden Meeting Nears, Erdogan Softens His Stance
description: With Trump gone and Turkey’s economy in crisis, the country’s strongman president is now trying to placate Western leaders rather than antagonize them. But how far can he be pushed?
content: ISTANBUL — For the last four years, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan has brazenly crushed his opponents at home and cozied up to Moscow, while showering his allies with sweetheart government contracts and deploying troops regionally wherever he saw fit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wilson
title: Long-Buried Secrets: The Serial Killer and the Detective
description: For decades, a string of killings of teenage girls haunted suburban New Jersey. A local investigator began to wonder: Could there be a link to a series of infamous Times Square murders?
content: A woman walking to her car found them: two teenage girls, naked and dead in a sliver of woods behind an apartment parking lot. They were facedown, side by side, as if placed there with care. “A horrible scene,” the police commissioner said that day. “Like two little dolls at Christmastime.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David M. Halbfinger
title: Netanyahu, ‘King of Israel,’ Exits a Stage He Dominated
description: Israel’s longest-serving prime minister was a polarizing figure who sidelined efforts to resolve the Palestinian conflict but opened relations with four Arab countries.
content: JERUSALEM — He came to power like some conqueror from a distant land called Philadelphia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roberta Smith
title: The Met Museum Sees More Clay in Its Future
description: An abstract painter found his place as a great collector of American ceramics. His latest gift ushers the Metropolitan Museum of Art into the 21st century.
content: Ceramics has come a remarkably long, raucous way since the early 1950s. That’s when Peter Voulkos, inspired by Abstract Expressionist painting, upended the medium with an increased scale, ambition and an improvisatory energy that mixed wheel-thrown with hand built forms. Since then, some ceramists — Ken Price to Betty Woodman to Kathy Butterly — have simply assumed their work was part of the mainstream. They and others have appeared regularly in big exhibitions like the Whitney Biennial and they’ve been taken on by major galleries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: Thousands Rally in Brooklyn to Protest ‘State of Emergency’ for Trans Youth
description: The Brooklyn Liberation march took place amid a wave of legislation targeting transgender children and violence that disproportionately affects Black trans women. “We are here to claim space,” one speaker said.
content: When thousands gathered in Brooklyn last summer to participate in a march for Black trans lives, Shéár Avory was at home, helping to care for their family in the middle of the coronavirus pandemic. But Mx. Avory, who is transgender and nonbinary, was heartened by what they saw online: images and videos of a sea of people, dressed in white, rallying for their community.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Demonizing Critical Race Theory
description: These initiatives that Republicans whipped up to rail against are usually not a problem, but rather a wandering outrage in search of a problem.
content: Critical race theory is the political right’s new boogeyman.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Das, Gabriela Bhaskar and Karsten Moran
title: Westminster Dog Show Photos: Judgment Day
description: Who really is Best in Show when they’re all so photogenic?
content: [Follow our live coverage of the Westminster dog show.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlotte Cowles
title: The Week in Business: Prices Are Rising on Cars, Groceries and Even Burritos
description: It’s not your imagination — prices on consumer goods have risen quickly. But is that really a cause for concern?
content: Good morning and happy Sunday. Here’s what you need to know in business and tech news for the week ahead. — Charlotte Cowles
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: Experts warn that the drop in U.S. testing will make it harder to track outbreaks.
description: Dangerous variants are spreading, and only 43 percent of the population has been fully vaccinated, as states reopen and travel resumes.
content: As coronavirus testing continues to decline in the United States, public health experts are warning that the trend will make it more difficult for the country to identify outbreaks and track the spread of highly contagious variants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Campbell
title: For the Islanders, the Good Times Really Are Here Again
description: Four Stanley Cups in the 1980s gave way to bad decisions and bad luck. But the Islanders, one of the last four teams remaining in the N.H.L. playoffs, are finally on a roll.
content: There are scenes you almost never see at a N.H.L. arena, unless everything is going right.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: President Biden says Queen Elizabeth reminds him of his mother.
description: The American president and first lady had tea with the queen at Windsor Castle, after the Group of 7 summit ended.
content: President Biden called Queen Elizabeth “extremely gracious” and said she reminded him of his mother after a meeting at Windsor Castle on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: For England, a Six-Second Culture War and a One-Goal Win
description: A cause, and criticism of it, only highlights that the majority of England fans all want the same thing.
content: LONDON — Daniele Orsato caught the eye of Harry Kane, the England captain, and pointed to the turf. He had caught Kane a little unaware, perhaps — the forward was still going through a final few stretches — but he nodded his assent. Orsato, the Italian referee, put his whistle to his lips, and gave light to a six-second culture war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere
title: F.D.A. details failures at a Baltimore plant that led to unusable vaccine doses.
description: The F.D.A. advised Johnson & Johnson on Friday that it should throw out the equivalent of 60 million doses produced at the Baltimore plant.
content: A Baltimore factory that rendered useless 75 million doses of a coronavirus vaccine developed by Johnson & Johnson failed for weeks to seal off a preparation area for vaccine ingredients and allowed production waste to be hauled through the area, the Food and Drug Administration said in a memorandum analyzing the plant’s operations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert M. Gates
title: We Cannot Afford to Turn Our Backs on Afghanistan
description: Many Americans want  this painful chapter closed, but supporting Afghanistan remains in our national security interest.
content: Within a few weeks, the last U.S. troops will leave Afghanistan, ending a military engagement that began 20 years ago this October. More than 2,300 of our finest have been killed, and more than 20,000 were wounded. More than 71,000 Afghan and Pakistani civilians have died as a direct result of the war. We have spent much blood and much treasure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Queen Elizabeth II Welcomed the Bidens to a Private Tea at Windsor
description: President Biden and the first lady seemed relaxed, and there were no obvious diplomatic breaches.
content: CARBIS BAY, England — Queen Elizabeth II was a spry presence at the Group of 7 meeting in Cornwall, England, on Friday, wisecracking during a group photo with world leaders and cutting a cake with a sword. But on Sunday, when she welcomed President Biden and the first lady, Jill Biden, to her own home, Windsor Castle, it was a very private visit, with cameras and reporters kept well away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Lee
title: For Literary Novelists the Past Is Pressing
description: Historical fiction was once considered a fusty backwater. Now the genre is having a renaissance, attracting first-rank novelists and racking up major prizes.
content: In an interview in 2012, Hilary Mantel, the author of the “Wolf Hall” trilogy, was asked if she felt any trepidation writing about the Tudors. “Much historical fiction that centers on real people has always been deficient in information, lacking in craft and empty in affect,” she replied. Then she added, with a hint of Cromwellian confidence: “I thought I could do better.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: Review: The Compassion of ‘A Thousand Ways (Part Two)’
description: The experimental company 600 Highwaymen is back with theater of the most intimate kind, starring you and a stranger at close range.
content: “So once you go inside,” the usher instructed me at the Public Theater on Saturday, “you’re going to walk onto the stage, and you’re going to take the seat farthest from the door.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anand Giridharadas
title: Warren Buffett and the Myth of the ‘Good Billionaire’
description: There is no way to be a billionaire in America without taking advantage of a system predicated on cruelty.
content: Warren Buffett appears to be the safest kind of billionaire: the good kind. Mr. Buffett is neither Zuckerbergian messiah nor Musky provocateur, neither Bezosist space cadet nor Sacklerian undertaker. He is, or seems to be, quiet, humble, indifferent to money, philanthropic and critical of the system that allowed him to rise. Years ago, a proposed tax increase was named after him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roxanne Khamsi
title: Pfizer, AstraZeneca … or Both? A Mixed Approach May Hold Promise.
description: Scientists are studying mix-and-matching vaccines for Covid-19 and other diseases.
content: At the start of the Covid-19 pandemic, it was unclear whether researchers would be able to create a single working vaccine, which makes it all the more surprising that the latest immunization dilemma arises from having multiple vaccine options.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Terence McGinley
title: Thinking Often of the Pentagon Papers
description: This weekend, a special section in The Times commemorates the 50th anniversary of the Pentagon Papers. Here, contributors to the project reflect on how the secret study’s publication influenced their careers.
content: Fifty years ago today, The Times published the first article in its series on the Pentagon Papers, the Defense Department’s secret study of the United States’ role in Vietnam. The papers, including private revelations that ran counter to the public optimism of leaders, changed American journalism and a nation’s relationship with its government. The Nixon administration’s attempt to stop The Times from printing its series, and the Supreme Court decision that allowed the paper to continue, is a landmark First Amendment case. In a special section, rolled out online last week and in newspapers this weekend, Times journalists and contributors wrote about these themes. Here’s what they think about when the Pentagon Papers come to mind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard
title: Israel’s Arab neighbors predict little change in relations.
description: Though Benjamin Netanyahu helped land normalization deals with important regional neighbors, those countries don’t see him as indispensable.
content: If the end of Benjamin Netanyahu’s 12-year reign as prime minister is a political earthquake inside Israel, its tremors stop clearly at Israel’s borders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Wrap fried chicken and biscuits in wax paper to share, and head outside.
content: Good morning. Sundays were big cooking days for me, before the pandemic came. I liked to cook large meals and serve them early, to whomever wanted to come, to whomever was hungry, craved connection or needed the meal. I liked the idea of feeding family and friends, the occasional stranger. I liked what the meals brought to those who partook of them. And I liked the regularity of the feeding as much as the food itself. It was a kind of weekly service, something to look forward to, for me and for others. (With impeccable timing, I wrote a book about all this that came out … just before the lockdowns began.)
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: June 13, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, June 13, 2021.
content: An article on Page 11 this weekend about the (Un)Known Project in Louisville, Ky., misattributes a line in Hannah Drake’s poem “Dawn.” Drake, in an asterisk, attributes the line in her poem to Anne Lamott. (It is from Lamott’s book “Bird by Bird.”) It also misidentifies the year Drake’s video won millions of views and praise from Ava DuVernay. DuVernay’s comments and millions of views occurred in 2019, not 2017, when Drake made the video.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Four new breeds joined the party this year.
description: The barbet, Belgian Laekenois, Biewer terrier and Dogo Argentino are all in.
content: More than 200 breeds are recognized by the American Kennel Club and are therefore eligible for the Westminster show. The four new entrants in 2021 are:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronen Bergman
title: The new government is expected to hold the line on big security issues.
description: Topics like a Palestinian state, or starting new hostilities with Syria and Hezbollah, could blow the coalition apart over the member’s ideological issues.
content: Members of the new Israeli government put together by Naftali Bennett, the new prime minister, have referred to their coalition as a “government of change.” But a big question is whether there will be changes in Israel’s foreign and defense policies, which have been almost exclusively controlled by Benjamin Netanyahu since 2009, when he began his last term in office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Klein
title: What the Rich Don’t Want to Admit About the Poor
description: Why do we leave millions of people in poverty? The answer should make us uncomfortable.
content: I’m not going to pretend that I know how to interpret the jobs and inflation data of the past few months. My view is that this is still an economy warped by the pandemic, and that the dynamics are so strange and so unstable that it will be some time before we know its true state. But the reaction to the early numbers and anecdotes has revealed something deeper and more constant in our politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather and Jonathan Ellis
title: Here’s how to watch the 2021 Westminster dog show.
description: Winners from three groups will be named on Sunday night. They’ll join four other group winners to compete for Best in Show.
content: You’re in the right place: The New York Times will have live commentary from our, uh, experts, beginning tonight at 7:30 Eastern time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marisa Ingemi
title: Chris Hogan Left Lacrosse. A League Has Given Him, and Others, a Path Back.
description: The former N.F.L. wide receiver has joined the Premier Lacrosse League, where pros in other sports have found opportunities on the field.
content: In high school, Chris Hogan didn’t see a path forward in lacrosse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Schmidt and Charlie Savage
title: Apple Is Said to Have Turned Over Data on Trump’s White House Counsel in 2018
description: The company notified Donald F. McGahn II last month that it had been subpoenaed for his account information three years ago.
content: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department subpoenaed Apple for information in February 2018 about an account that belonged to Donald F. McGahn II, President Donald J. Trump’s White House counsel at the time, and barred the company from telling him about it, according to two people briefed on the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Das
title: Denmark’s team doctor on Christian Eriksen: ‘He was gone.’
description: Eriksen went into cardiac arrest on the field during a game at Euro 2020, team officials said. His teammates will return to training on Monday.
content: Denmark’s team doctor said Christian Eriksen went into cardiac arrest during a game at Euro 2020 on Saturday and that “he was gone” before lifesaving treatment on the field resuscitated him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear, Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Marc Santora
title: G7 leaders come together on a global minimum tax and democratic ideals.
description: The Group of 7 joint communiqué marks a return of international diplomacy but offers few concrete steps to achieve the summit’s lofty goals.
content: As the leaders of the world’s wealthiest nations wrapped up their first in-person summit since the outbreak of the pandemic, they released a joint communiqué on Sunday, underscoring areas of solidarity — and the differences that remain — when it comes to tackling a host of global crises.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Binyamin Appelbaum
title: The Tax Pirates Are Us
description: American policymakers have sabotaged the nation’s ability to collect taxes from its corporations. Will Congress agree to change course?
content: The decline of corporate taxation in recent decades is generally blamed on pirate states like Luxembourg, Ireland and Bermuda, which offer an alluring combination of very low tax rates and an unembarrassed enthusiasm for allowing companies to play make-believe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Maine Residents Fend Off Poisonous Caterpillars
description: The caterpillars, known as browntail moths, have tiny hairs that can cause skin rashes and even breathing issues for some people.
content: While parts of the country deal with swarms of cicadas this summer, Maine is struggling with an infestation of an invasive species of caterpillar with poisonous hairs that can cause people to develop painful rashes and even breathing problems.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeré Longman and Romain Molina
title: World Basketball Chief Steps Aside Amid Sexual Abuse Investigation
description: Hamane Niang, the leader of basketball’s global governing body known as FIBA, led Mali’s federation at a time of systemic exploitation of female players, activists say. FIBA announced an investigation.
content: After helping to build the West African nation of Mali into a women’s basketball power, a remarkable achievement for one of the world’s poorest countries, Hamane Niang was elected in 2019 as the president of the sport’s global governing body.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger and Michael D. Shear
title: G7 Leaders Offer United Front as Summit Ends, but Cracks Are Clear
description: Biden and other Western leaders had tough words for Russia and China after wrapping up a meeting in England, but they had trouble finding common ground on some big issues.
content: BRUSSELS — President Biden and fellow Western leaders issued a confrontational declaration about Russian and Chinese government behavior on Sunday, castigating Beijing over its internal repression, vowing to investigate the pandemic’s origins, and excoriating Moscow for using nerve agents and cyberweapons.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheila Kaplan
title: Judge dismisses Houston hospital workers’ lawsuit over vaccination mandate.
description: The decision appeared to be among the first to rule in favor of employer-mandated vaccinations for workers.
content: A federal judge in Texas has dismissed a lawsuit brought by employees of Houston Methodist Hospital who had challenged the hospital’s Covid vaccination requirement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Netanyahu angrily vows to his supporters, ‘I will lead you in a daily battle.’
description: Benjamin Netanyahu, Israel’s longest-serving leader, spent what might be his last minutes in power by defending his record, promising to remain in politics as leader of the opposition, and denouncing his nominated successor, Naftali Bennett.
content: Benjamin Netanyahu, Israel’s longest-serving leader, spent what might be his last minutes in power by defending his record, promising to remain in politics as leader of the opposition, and denouncing his nominated successor, Naftali Bennett.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $600,000
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nadav Gavrielov
title: In Tel Aviv, a dance party celebrates the exit of the ‘crime minister.’
description: People thronged Rabin Square, cheering over the removal of a divisive prime minister, but worrying about the new one.
content: Ecstatic Israelis descended onto Tel Aviv’s Rabin Square on Sunday for a celebration marking the ouster of Benjamin Netanyahu and the swearing-in of a new — if precarious — government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: $4.5 Million Settlement in Police Killing of Alton Sterling, Lawyers Say
description: The settlement came nearly five years after Mr. Sterling, a Black father of five, was fatally shot by a white police officer in Baton Rouge, La.
content: The family of Alton Sterling, a Black man who was shot and killed by a white police officer outside a convenience store in Baton Rouge, La., has reached a $4.5 million settlement with the city, nearly five years after his death, the family’s lawyers said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noele Illien
title: Swiss Voters Reject Proposal to Ban Synthetic Pesticides
description: The referendum would have barred the use of the synthetic pesticides in farms and gardens.
content: ZURICH — Voters in Switzerland on Sunday overwhelmingly rejected a measure that would have banned the use of artificial pesticides in Switzerland, preventing their use in farms and gardens, and prohibited the import of produce and products made using them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Rasgon
title: Young Israelis see the end of their forever prime minister.
description: Israel’s youth are as divided as their country. But even some on the right saw Benjamin Netanyahu’s departure as a chance for change.
content: After 12 years with Benjamin Netanyahu as prime minister, young Israelis and Palestinians — who can barely remember his predecessor — expressed in interviews before Sunday’s vote a wide range of reactions to the possibility of a future without Mr. Netanyahu at the helm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear, Lisa Friedman and Catrin Einhorn
title: G7 Nations Take Aggressive Climate Action but Hold Back on Coal
description: President Biden pushed climate action after four years in which Donald Trump rejected cooperation with allies. But leaders failed to set an expiration date for burning coal.
content: BRUSSELS — President Biden joined with leaders of the world’s wealthiest nations on Sunday to take action aimed at holding down global temperatures, but failed to set a firm end date on the burning of coal, which is a primary contributor to global warming.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marzano-Lesnevich
title: The Healing Power of Queer Coming-of-Age Stories
description: New Y.A. literature, television and film let me imagine a better future.
content: Three episodes into “First Day,” an Australian series on Hulu aimed at middle schoolers, I realized I was going to cry. The protagonist, a tween trans girl named Hannah, had just been outed at her new school, horrifyingly compounding the trauma that had driven her from her previous one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: The Knesset is voting now on Bennett’s coalition.
description: If it is approved, a new government will remove Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and end two years of political gridlock.
content: The political fate of Israel’s longest serving leader, Benjamin Netanyahu, is set to be decided on Sunday afternoon, when Parliament will hold a vote of confidence in a new government that would topple Mr. Netanyahu from power for the first time in 12 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Now Halfway to a Grand Slam, Novak Djokovic Wins the French Open
description: Djokovic rallied to win three straight sets and defeat Stefanos Tsitsipas. It was his 19th major men’s singles title overall and his second this year.
content: PARIS — Novak Djokovic beat Stefanos Tsitsipas of Greece to win the French Open on Sunday, coming back from two sets down for his second stunning triumph in less than 48 hours.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Das
title: Denmark’s Christian Eriksen is stable condition but remains in the hospital.
description: Denmark’s soccer federation said the midfielder who collapsed during a Euro 2020 match on Saturday had sent greetings to his teammates.
content: Christian Eriksen was in “stable” condition in a Copenhagen hospital, Denmark’s soccer federation said in a statement on Sunday, a day after he collapsed and received life-saving medical treatment on the field during a Euro 2020 match against Finland.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: In Adesanya, U.F.C. Has a Champion It Can Depend On
description: Mainstream U.F.C. titleholders have slipped in recent years. So far, Adesanya has been consistent.
content: GLENDALE, Ariz. — As the lights dimmed inside Gila River Arena while Israel Adesanya and Marvin Vettori circled to the center of the octagon, a fan screamed a request to the Ultimate Fighting Championship’s middleweight champion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Cherelus
title: Quinta Brunson’s Viral Fame Knows No Bounds
description: The comedian’s first book, “She Memes Well,” balances jokes, autobiography and serious thoughts about the state of the country.
content: When she began drafting her first collection of essays, Quinta Brunson wasn’t sure she had anything meaningful to say.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Kitroeff, Maria Abi-Habib, James Glanz, Oscar Lopez, Weiyi Cai, Evan Grothjan, Miles Peyton and Alejandro Cegarra
title: Why the Mexico City Metro Collapsed
description: A Times investigation shows the serious construction flaws and political pressure behind a tragedy that threatens two of Mexico’s most prominent figures.
content: A Times investigation shows the serious construction flaws and political pressure behind a tragedy that threatens two of Mexico’s most prominent figures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: ‘She Reminded Me of My Mother,’ Biden Says of Queen Elizabeth II
description: After President Biden and the first lady, Jill Biden, met with Queen Elizabeth II at Windsor Castle on Sunday, Mr. Biden told reporters that the queen was “very gracious” and reminded him of his mother.
content: After President Biden and the first lady, Jill Biden, met with Queen Elizabeth II at Windsor Castle on Sunday, Mr. Biden told reporters that the queen was “very gracious” and reminded him of his mother.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Gratitude for Doctors Risking Their Lives Treating Covid Patients
description: Readers praise young doctors for their selflessness. Also: Jimmy Carter's U.F.O. sighting; the need for a federal gun law; pandemic pets.
content: To the Editor:
